record.title: [Praises of Saint Mary, Blessed Virgin, and gate of light].
record.note: Manuscript in red and black, one column, 14 lines per page. F.1rv and f.58rv appear to be leaves (a bifolium?) discarded from another manuscript, covered with pen trials.
Wooden boards, four chain stitches; one column; 14 lines per page.
F. 57r: Prayer by one Gabra Selassie to Mary to “keep me in body and soul.” A secondary hand adds the name Gabra Maryam.

record.title: [Prayer of Our Lady Mary at Golgotha, mystagogia, sword of divinity, and bandlet of righteousness].
record.note: In red and black, bound in leather between wooden boards, one column, 13-14 lines per page. Flyleaves contain images of Mary, Jesus, and Michael. Some decorative headpieces. Some marginalia.
F. 1r: Note: Edited by ግዛቸው ወልዴ ነው, written in an untrained hand; F. 4r mentions the owner, ወልደ ሚካኤል; Blank: ii v, iii rv. 53v.
Illuminations: F. 1v: Madonna and Child, flanked by the angels Gabriel and Michael; F. 2r: Angel with drawn sword and scabbard.

record.title: [Computus of Demetrius of Alexandria].
record.note: In red and black ink, 3 columns, 24 to 29 lines per page. Flyleaves are sown together. Detailed decorative headpieces throughout. Some sections intentionally blotted out (e.g. f. 10). Some marginalia. Some tears and holes sewn back together. F. 48ff. contain numerical, calendrical, and astronomical charts.

record.title: [Bandlet of righteousness].
record.note: Manuscript in black and red ink. First page contains a decorative cross. Substantial damage to some pages. A description of the object is given: "The little scroll belongs to the common literature of Lefafa sedq (bandlet of truth), principally used for burial with the deceased. That is, prayers of Mary, here the part called the Mashafa heywat (book of life). It is represented by innumerable copies in libraries and elsewhere."

record.title: [Funeral ritual].
record.note: In black and red ink, bound between wooden covers with four chain stitches, two columns, 18-20 lines per page.

Some decorative headpieces. Some graffiti in flyleaves. Handwritten note (20th century) between f. 3 and f. 4: "apparently liturgy (prayers [selot], lessons from the gospels, etc.)". The Beinecke's cover for the book reads "Lectionary," which conflicts with the internal note's claims concerning the text.
F. 120v: Note of ownership: the name of the owner has been erased. After a set of lines creating a unit division is a list of names of family members and also of the scribe, ዜና ገብርኤል እልፍዮስ.

record.title: [Psalter, followed by canticles, Song of Songs, praises of Mary, and gate of light].
record.note: Half bound with leather between wooden boards, the front board being broken and stitched; four chain stitches. One column (ff. 1r-148r), two columns (ff. 149r-167v). In red and black ink.

Flyleaf contains depiction of royal figure with a harp (David?) and other figures. Some decorative headpieces, including images of houses and pyramids(?). f. 43 contains a depiction of St. George and the Dragon. Some holes and tears sewn back together. Final section of book contains a narrative including Mary. f. 148 contains a depiction of a woman (Mary?) carrying a cross, a man carrying two vessels, and two ghostly figures floating above.

Illuminations: F. ii v: David playing his harp (the scene is depicted with David’s body in profile, though his face shows both eyes), before him (right) are three people; One (at the bottom) lies prostrate and holds shield and rifle; A second stands before David with a Psalter in hand; Above, a third holds a sword over his shoulder; A crude hand has written, “This Psalter belongs to ቄስ መሬ;” F. 43v: Saint George and the Dragon, caption: ቅዱስ ጊዮር[ጊ]ስ; F. 148v: Saint Mary, (right) holding hand cross, before Saint Ephrem(?) (left) also holding objects in his hands, above two angels hover over Mary.

F. ii: stamp of the Yale University Library; F. 162r mentions the scribe (ጸሐፊሁ), ኃይለ [the second name is erased]; Inside back cover: owner plate of the Yale University Library: Gift of Thomas Ewart Marston; Blank: Ff. irv, 168rv, 169v; F. 167v: record: Scribal note of completion: “the end of the Dawit on Tahsas 11 in the peace of God.”

record.title: [Psalter, calendar, biblical canticles, Song of Songs, praises of Mary, and gate of light].
record.note: In black and red ink. Half bound with leather, between wooden boards, the front one of which is broken and stitched. Four chain stitches, one column (ff. 5r-155r), two columns (ff. 155v-169v). Substantial marginalia. Some later editorial decorations added in a crayon-like substance. Some lacunae have been patched and rewritten. Some holes and tears have been sewn back together.

F. 1r: text: pen trial; F. 1v: text: Calendar, in an 18th century hand; F. 2r–3v, upper: text, in a 19th century hand; F. 3v, lower and 4r, lower: text, in a 20th century hand; F. 4v: text: calendar; F. 151r, bottom margin: note of secondary ownership, ገብረ ጊዎርጊስ, written in a later hand.

record.title: [Canticle of the flower, lamentations of the Virgin, image of Mary, and image of the Trinity].
record.note: In red and black ink. One column, 13-14 lines per page.

The flyleaf contains a depiction of four figures (perhaps including Mary and Jesus?). Some crayon-like headpieces in purple, orange, and green. f. 44 contains later Ethiopic additions written in pen. Minimal marginalia. The final flyleaves contain graffiti crosses and pencil writing.
Illuminations : F. 2v: Madonna and Child with the Angels Mika’el and Gabri’el behind; Ff. 90v and 91r: drawings of the fraction of the host.

Notes: F. 3r mentions an owner, ኃይለ ማርያም; Blank: 90r; F. 91v: Record dated in 1948, Tahsas 28, regarding the sale of the book of Canticle of the Flower for 6 birr, witnesses are listed; at the end, “to not deny the selling of the book, I put my fingerprint.” There are fingerprints and signatures of the parties. “If I change my word, may Haile Selassie die".

record.title: [Psalter, biblical canticles, Song of Songs, praises of Mary, and gate of light].
record.note: In red and black ink. Bound between wooden boards with four chain stitches. One column (ff. 3r-127r); two columns (ff. 127v-140r), 26-27 lines per page.

f. 1 is upside down, yet the graffiti is correctly oriented. Ethiopic graffiti in the flyleaf (f. 2). Some marginalia and penciled-in decorations. Sections (?) are numerated in the margins in pencil. Some holes and tears sewn back together.
F. 2v: Note of ownership; F. 138r: prayers for the owner and others.

record.title: [Psalter, biblical canticles, Song of Songs, praises of Mary, and gate of light].
record.note: Leather bound between wooden boards with four chain stitchees. One column (ff. 1r-168v); two columns (ff. 169r-184v), 19 lines per page. In red and black ink.

Some marginalia. Numeration on the top margins of some pages (to count quires?). Some holes and tears sewn back together. Some pages excised before modern numeration. Occasional symbols in body of text.

record.title: [Mawaśʻet and zemāré chants].
record.note: In black and red ink. Bound between wooden boards, with four chain stitches, one column, 16-20 lines per page. Some holes and tears sewn back together. Occasional pages of different sizes throughout.

record.title: [Prayer of Our Lady Mary at Golgotha, absolution of the Son, collection of prayers].
record.note: Ff. 1v and 10r mention the owner, ገብራ ወልደ ጻድቅ, [female]; f. 9r mentions another owner, ሐዋዘ ብርሃን, [male]; Ff. 1r, 10v–14r are blank.
In red and black ink, single quire from a book, with no covers, two columns, 23-28 lines per page.

record.title: [Magic scroll of spiritual healing].
record.note: Scroll on parchment, one column. Tears in parchment sewn back together. Illustration of two figures carrying a large cross and a seraphic figure. Leather strap on the top of the scroll.
The owner is never mentioned.

record.title: [Miracles of Mary].
record.note: Leather bound between wooden boards with four chain stitches. In black and red ink. Three columns, 26-27 lines per page. There is fine cloth between the turndowns on the inside back cover.

Detailed illustrations in the first flyleaves, depicting Mary, among many other human and angelic figures. Decorative headpieces throughout. Some marginalia. Numerical markings at the beginning of each quire. Various illuminated pages throughout the text depicting the life and miracles of Mary.
1868-1913 (ff. 5r and passim) mention Emperor Menilek, 1868–1913; and f. 195v mentions Ras Mikael of Wollo, 1850–1918); the harags also indicate production in the Menilek scriptorium.

1. The last of the miracles (ff. 193v–195v) is written in a different hand and dated in the time of “Our King Mika’el,” i.e., Ras Mikael of Wollo, 1850–1918.; 2. Inside cover contains the ownership plate of Yale University Library, Gift of Laurence and Cora Witten; 3. f. ir: written in the upper left corner [12210]; 4. Ff. i v–ii r, iii v, and 69r are blank.

record.title: Order authorizing payment to Jonathan Forward for transporting convicts to the American plantations : manuscript / R. Walpole ; Charels Turner ; Richard Edgecombe.
record.note: In brown ink on cream laid paper.

record.title: [Magic scroll of spiritual healing].
record.note: Scroll on parchment, two columns, black and red ink.
The scroll was made for ወለተ ሩፋኤል.

record.title: [Synaxarium].
record.note: Ordered by Abba Mikaʼel and Abba Yohannes.
Volumes in wooden boards, with four chain stitches, three columns, 34-38 lines per page, in red and black ink.

V.1: Synaxarium for the first part of the year: F. 1r mentions the ones who ordered the book: Abba Mika’el, whose country is አትሪብ (in Egypt?), Abba Yohannes, whose country is ቡርልስ. F. 163v contains further information about the book; the two volumes of the Synaxarium were purchased by ገብረ ማርያም, with his own money for two ወቂት; the record also mentions other books he bought; thereafter, the record (continuing on f. 165r) mentions a list of purchased books owned by the church, 20 books in all, as well other church utensils and priestly garments, crosses; another record lists books given by other people with a curse on anyone who steals or erases; a final record, written in a different hand, lists more books and materials given to the church; f. 164v contains the name plate of Yale University Library, the Edwin J. Beinecke Fund

V.2: Synaxarium for the second part of the year: 1868–1913 (f. 61v mentions Emperor Menilek,1868–1913, and Governor Ras Hailu,1868–1950); f. 1r mentions the ones who ordered the book: Abba Mika’el, whose country is አትሪብ (in Egypt?), Abba Yohannes, whose country is ቡርልስ. 1. f. i r: owner plate: Yale University Library; The Edwin J. Beinecke Fund; 2. f. i v: Pen trial, written in trained hand; 3. f. ii r: An incomplete record, mentioning the dates Genbot 5, and 19, written in an untrained hand; 4. f. ii r, bottom: another incomplete record mentioning Miyazia 25 and 26, Sane 17 and Arias, the heretic, written in an untrained hand; 5. ff. 2v and 194v are blank. F. 44r has the name ወልደ ሰንባት, written into the blank, written in a different hand; f. 61v has a note of ownership in a different hand: This book belongs to the church, ዋሻ ሚካኤል during the time of Emperor Menilek (1868–1913) and Governor (Ras) Hailu (1858–1950), and Qängazmač Alemu, and church manager ቄሰ ገበዝ ተገኝ, and Märigeta ዛይህመ, church scholar, in the year of Evangelist Saint John, it was purchased. ቄሰ ገበዝ ተገኝ, whose baptismal name is ወልደ ተንሣኤ, is the one bought it as the property of the church ዋሻ ሚካኤል; it appears that the hand changes half way through f. 86v.

record.title: [Missal].
record.note: 1721–1726 (f. 1r mentions the 7,221st year of creation [=1721], and “the month of February (Yakatit) ... in the time of our King, Bakafa [1721–1730]; f. 19v mentions Abba Petros = Peter VI, 1718–1726, and Abba Krestodolu III, 1720–1735; the overlap between the three dates—king, Coptic Patriarch, and Ethiopian Abuna—is 1721–1726); the colophon itself mentions the eighth year of Bakafa’s reign, i.e., 1729.

Introductory colophon to the manuscript: "In the name of the Father and Son and Holy Spirit, one God. How we remember the calculation of the year of our Lord Jesus Christ since we are in the year of Matthew the Evangelist, may He keep us until the year of Mark (the Evangelist), in the 7,221st year of creation [=1721], since there is no epact for [the ringing of] its bell, the month of February (Yakatit), the fourth day and seventh night, in the time of our King, Bakafa [1721-1730], in the eighth year after he became king, this book was written." [Text is damaged.]
F. 19v mentions Abba Petros = Peter VI, 1718–1726, and Abba Krestodolu III, 1720–1735. The overlap between the three dates (King and Coptic Patriarch and Ethiopian Abuna) is 1721–1726.

In wooden boards, with four chain stitches, leather bound, two columns, 22-23 lines per page, black and red ink. Fine fabric is visible between the pastedowns of the front and back covers. Double slip mahdar.

record.title: [Code of kings].
record.note: Leather bound, perhaps in the West.
19th century (the note in the front suggests early-19th century when Henry Salt was in Adwa).

Notes: 1. f. i r(ecto): “[..lnyed?] to Henry Salt. Sent to him from Adwa by Nathaniel Pierce;” Inside front cover has an ownership plate of Yale University Library, gift of Thomas Ewart Marston, Yale [1927 (out of focus)]; f. 297v: note of completion and gifting of the book.

record.title: [150 Psalms of David].
record.note: Note of content: "Psalms of David, translated into Tigrê by Debtera Matheos at Adoa. Unrevised," with comments nearby in a different hand: "Henry Salt's writing; Sent to him from Adwa by Nathaniel Pearce."
Leather bound, one column, 19 lines, running header.
Foliated in the upper right recto.

record.title: [Acts of the Apostles, Epistles, and Revelation].
record.note: Note of content: "Acts, Epistles & Revelation, translated by Debtera Matheos into Tigrê. Unrevised", with comments nearby in a different hand: "Henry Salt's writing; Sent to him from Adwa by Nathaniel Pearce".
Leather bound, one column, 19-20 lines, running header.
Foliated in the upper right recto.

record.title: [The story of Mary and Ephrem and the composition of the Praises of Mary, gate of light, book of Mohammad Grañ, and image of Saint George zaSalédā Mogas].
record.note: : Notes: 1. F. ii r(ecto): A list of names of a leading judge and priest of the region of ዐፎሊ ምድር; there follows at least three more names of people; the names appear to be of Oromo people; 2. ff. 6r, 12v and passim, mention an owner ቅብዓ ሥላሲ. 3. f. 58r mentions another owner(?), ወልደ ማርያም; 4. f. 19r mentions the scribe, ገብረ ኪዳን; 5. frame 109v mention later owners(?) or family members, written in a later hand: ገብረ ማርያም, ወልደ ማርያም, ወልዳ ኢየሱስ.
With leather case.
One of the scribes was Gabre Kidān.
Between wooden boards, with four chain stitches, one column, 13 lines per page, in black and red ink.

record.title: Peter Delmé Esqr. bill from Edward Peirce, December 1764 : manuscript.
record.note: Devised title. Docket title on verso: 15th Dect. 1764 Edwd. Pierce for thatching at Posbrooks pd. £5:17:2.

record.title: 19 famous recipes.
record.note: Written in black ink, with headings in red.

record.title: A perspective view of Dilston Hall, once the seat of the unfortunate James, Earl of Derwent-Water [graphic] / T. Oliver delin. ; Spilsbury sculp., Russel-Court, London.
record.note: Title engraved above image.
Plate signed below image.
Verses below image begin: How mournful feeble nature's tone, when Dilston-Hall appears ...

record.title: Spotter Card Trick.
record.note: Card game with 6 playing cards 5 of which are double playing cards. Ace of Club on all cards. 5 cards are 3, 4, and 5 of spades and 4 and 5 of clubs.
"Six cards including one Ace of Clubs are openly shown. The six cards are laid in a row. When one is chosen it is always the Ace."
"Full instructions and complete patter are included."
"Made in England."
"E & S. Copyight."

record.title: Merry Widow Hanky : a laugh on the girls.
record.note: "The girls get curious about the ruffles on the Handkerchief showing from your pocket. They think you have other sweethearts but when they investigate the hanky, AH! it is not a Handkerchief at all but something else, indeed!! Fold the hanky so that the lace protrudes frm the pocket--it won't take long for the fun to start."

Handkerchief, unfolded, is in the shape of a pair of lavender lace trimmed ladies underwear with the poem printed on them: Short but Sweet. Mary had some little pants/Too short were they to show/But everywhere that Mary went/The pants were sure to go. Accompanied by printed paper envelope.

record.title: Chevalier d'Eon letter to Counsellor Pigott regarding dispute over lease of a house in London, 1798 March 29 : autograph manuscript signed.
record.note: "Londres 29 mars 1798"--Page 1.
Final page blank.
Letter is folded at fore edge to fit into the book in which it is bound.

record.title: John Boyle Orrery letter, to Messrs. Dodsley, [not before 1754] : manuscript / Corke.
record.note: Date based on beginning of partnership of Robert and James Dodsley
Dodsley spelled "Dodseley" in the address.

record.title: George H. Thomas letter, Louisville, Kentucky, to George Pearson Buell, Lynchburg, Virginia, 1867 May 1 : manuscript.
record.note: Manuscript copy, unsigned, from Thomas's letterbook, possibly in an unidentified secretary's hand.

record.title: Harry Grover account book, 1783 July 18-1786 October 14 : manuscript.
record.note: Manuscript title in ink on front board: No. 1, Account book 18th July 1783 ending 14th October 1786.
Contemporary vellum front board; rebacked, with matching back board.

record.title: Francis M. Emerson letter, Canon Creek, California, to Susan Hunt Emerson, 1854 November 20 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is accompanied by a typed transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: J. J. Zimmerman letter, La Grange, California, to Franklin A. Hinds, Portland, Oregon, 1865 September 8 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is accompanied by a typed transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: Translation of a report by Álvaro de Bazan, marquês de Santa Cruz, on the defense of Spain and the West Indies from Sir Francis Drake : manuscript.
record.note: Provenance: Henry Stevens; Sir Thomas Phillipps; Paul Mellon.

record.title: 880-02 Tōdaiji-gire : manuscript.
record.note: Housed in a box inscribed by Yukio Fukuda.
Displayed at "Irodorareta kami ryōshi sōshoku," an exhibit at the Tokugawa Museum in 2001.
"Sanbō ekotoba, gekan, Sōbō, shigatsu, dai 17 , Taianji no daihanyae" no dankan.

record.title: Indictment of Claude-Louis-François Régnier, comte de Guerchy for conspiring to assassinate Charles Geneviève Louis Auguste André Timothée d'Eon : manuscript fragment.
record.note: Indictment alleges that on October 31 in the fourth year of the reign of George III (that is, 1763), the comte de Guerchy attempted to hire Peter Henry Treyssac de Vergy to assassinate d'Eon.
Includes at end a separate certification of authenticity written in French by d'Eon, at London, dated 18 September 1767.
Paginated 147-148.

record.title: Corrine Nishimura autograph album : manuscript.
record.note: Disbound by a former owner.

record.title: Indenture placing William Spill into the service of William Beales, broad weaver.
record.note: "This indenture witnesseth that [William Spill], one of the poor [boys] of the charity-school of [the parish of Wotton Underedge in the County of Gloucester to the one part] doth put h[im]self apprentice to [William Beales of the parish of Wotton Underedge aforesd. broad weaver of the other part] to learn h[is] art, and with h[im] after the manner of an apprentice to serve from the day of the date hereof, unto the full end and term of [seven] years ... And the said M[aster], (in consideration of the sum of [three] pounds paid to [him] ... ) ... shall teach and instruct, or cause to be taught and instructed, finding unto his said apprentice, meat drink apparel, lodging, washing, and all other necessaries ... In witness thereof, the parties above named to these indentures interchangeably have put their hands and seals the [eighth] day of [April], Anno Dom. 17[28] ... "

Additional provision written in manuscript, in the margin: "And also shall & will during the said term give and deliver unto his said apprentice six pence a quarter in money every quarter in every year during the said term; and at the end of the sd. term shall & will give and deliver unto his sd. apprentice one new suit of apparel."
"Sealed and delivered (being first duly stamp'd) in the presence of us, [Thomas Bisigar, John Cooke]"

At the head of the indenture is an engraved allegorical triptych. The center panel features a depiction of George III. At left, a young female student stands in front of "the Pillar of Faith" and bears a sign reading "And we as mothers of our Israel." At right, a young male student stands in front of "the Gate of Life" and bears a sign reading "In cause of Church & State may we Excell."
Includes a blind-embossed tax stamp.

record.title: Charles Cauchon de Maupas letter, Hinchingbrooke House, to Nicholas de Neufville, marquis de Villeroi, 1603 May 8 : manuscript.
record.note: Hinchingbrooke House appears as "Finchinbrook" in the letter.
Integral address panel directed to "Monsieur monsieur de Villeroy" with remains of a red wax seal.

record.title: Account book relating to railroad construction in Morrisania, New York : manuscript.
record.note: Bookseller's ticket: H. & S. Raynor, 76 Bowery, New York.

record.title: Henry Seymour daybook : manuscript.
record.note: Unidentified account book fragments from circa 1803-1807 used as binding paste-downs.

record.title: Letter : No. 36 Windmill Street Rathbone Place, to Richard Bull, 1784 December 18.
record.note: Tipped in at page 240 of Richard Bull's copiously extra-illustrated copy of: Walpole, H. A description of the villa of Mr. Horace Walpole. Strawberry Hill : Printed by Thomas Kirgate, 1784. See Hazen, A.T. Bibliography of the Strawberry Hill Press (1973 ed.), no. 30, copy 13.

record.title: Lace sample book.
record.note: In "Patent Self Binder" (no. 15868) made by Priestley & Swann, Ltd., Nottingham. The firm of Priestly & Swann was active from ca. 1895 until well into the 20th century.

record.title: Joseph Frothingham letter, Sacramento, California, to Elizabeth Ann Frothingham, Brooklyn, New York, 1850 April 1 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is accompanied by a typed transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: James E. Wisner letter, Lisbon, North Dakota, to an unidentified recipient, 1891 June 22 : manuscript.
record.note: No. 1 of 2 items housed together.

record.title: Parry commonplace book : manuscript.
record.note: Contemporary full paneled calf.

record.title: 880-01 Otorika tomegaki, undated.
record.note: Yale bookplate date: 1907.
On double leaves, traditional East Asian binding style (fukurotoji).

record.title: A. Decker diary : manuscript.
record.note: Diary is accompanied by a typed transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: Records of livestock brands in Taos County and Union County, New Mexico : manuscript.
record.note: Volume 1: Taos County, 1853-1878. Volume 2: Taos County, 1879-1886. Volume 3: Taos County, 1873-1899, and Union County, circa 1873-1899, with later manuscript additions dated 1907-1910.

record.title: Promissory note issued to John Fellowes : manuscript.
record.note: Laid in to a larger sheet of paper.

record.title: Letter, Nacogdoches, Texas, to Stephen F. Austin, 1831 January 3 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is accompanied by a typed English translation made by an unidentified translator.
Misdated as 1830 January 3, but letter was written after the Mexican law of April 6, 1830.

record.title: Passports of George Treherne Thomas.
record.note: Both passports are in contemporary wallet style bindings, with flaps intact. Both bear the gilt-stamped name of George Treherne Thomas.

record.title: L'Orfeo [microform] : tragicomedia per musica.
record.note: Manuscript of the libretto by Francesco Buti to the opera by Luigi Rossi.

record.title: Amos Mix letter, Knox County, Ohio, to David Frost, Waterbury, Connecticut, 1811 December 18 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is dated 1811 December 18, with an autograph postscript by Mix dated 1812 July 23.

record.title: The Oxford declarations.
record.note: Manuscript described in John Griffiths' manscript table of contents as "abstracts and remarks on the number of signatures to the three declarations" of the University of Oxford in 1834.
Catpion title.

"About 2670 persons were entitled to sign the three declarations. Of these a large number, say 170, were either abroad or ill or could not be found. There remain as dispentients about 485 : so that the opponents of the bill outnumbered its supporters in a greater ratio than that of four to one"--Page 1.

record.title: Korrespondenzen italienische Kardinäle und anderer Personen, besonders italiener, an Herzog Johann Friedrich.
record.note: Letters from Johann Friedrich's Italian correspondents between the years 1667-1679. Items of musical importance include letters of Francesco Maria Massi (210 letters, 1669-1676), Pietro Dolfino (58 letters, 1669-1678), Antonio Sartorio (18 letters, 1672-1679), and Nicolò Bérégan (27 letters, 1669-1678).
Detailed description in: Nel theatro di tutta l'Europa : Venetian-Hanoverian patronage in 17th-century Europe / Vassilis Vavoulis. Lucca : Libreria musicale italiana, c2010.

record.title: R. D. Mussey letter, Washington, D.C., to Nathaniel Prentiss Banks, 1866 March 21 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is accompanied by a typed transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: Charles Nichols letter, Fort Steilacoom, Washington, to William R. Thomas, 1861 May 9 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is accompanied by a manuscript transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: Edward Otho Cresap Ord letter to an unidentified recipient, 1849 : manuscript.
record.note: Letter is accompanied by a typed transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: Scrapbook of newspaper clippings from Liverpool newspapers concerning the trial of Queen Caroline : printed text.
record.note: Some clippings folded, others bound in; contemporary half roan morocco binding.

record.title: Sample books for printed cotton fabrics manufactured by Koechlin & Frères.
record.note: For more information on the dyeing of printed fabrics in general, and for mention of Koechlin dyes in particular, see: Greene, Susan W. Wearable prints, 1760-1860: history, materials, and mechanics. Kent, Ohio: The Kent State University Press, 2014. For a brief history of the Koechlin firm, see: Smith, Michael Stephen. The emergence of modern business enterprise in France, 1800-1930. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 2006 (pages 139-140).
Both volumes are bound in contemporary brown cloth.

record.title: J. Russell Hodge diary : manuscript.
record.note: Diary is accompanied by a partial typed transcription made by an unidentified transcriber.

record.title: [Ethiopian scroll of spiritual healing].
record.note: Scroll on parchment, one column, single-line borders, rubricated for the start of new prayers and for the names of the saints and for the name(s) of the owner(s).
Probably missing a third strip of parchment that would have carried final prayers and a third illumination.

record.title: [Folio from Eusebian canon table in a 15th century four Gospels manuscript].
record.note: Folio on parchment. This folio contains the first two canon tables, one on recto, one on verso.
Eleven (depending on how the tables are organized) additional canon tables are not present with this copy.

record.title: Jeu doigts.
record.note: Original collage in the form of a board game on 2 attached pieces of cardboard consisting of 63 rectangles (3 of them unnumbered) 58 x 54 mm and another cut-out image numbered 63 of Jesus with halo and his left arm raised. The image of Jesus overlaps the final rectangle. The rectangles are photos, most of them of exposed parts of female anatomy. In the center of the board is manuscript text "Règle du jeu-doigts. On y jouera comme au 'jeu de l'oie' ordinaire ..." signed: gaudryj 1964. The title is stenciled on front panel when folded. There is a partially erased presentation inscription signed "Gaudry 64" beneath title.

record.title: Excerpts from William Burkitt's Expository notes.
record.note: A note in a much later hand at the front of the album attributes the manuscript (presumably the copied text and the original drawings) to Mary Smith of Cropwell Butler, Nottinghamshire. The basis of this attribution is unclear.
In general text and illustration appear on one side of a leaf, usually on facing pages.
Leaves of the album are watermarked 1846.

record.title: Charles N. Morris letters, 1869 February 17-1882 December 6.
record.note: Letters accompanied by typescript transcriptions by an unidentified individual.

record.title: Edward DeLevan Barker diary, 1858 August 16-1860 April 1.
record.note: Diary accompanied by partial typed transcript made by an unidentified transcriber.
Diary accompanied by a photocopy.

record.title: Thomas Gainsborough letter to Elizabeth Rasse.
record.note: Written in black ink.
The sheet was previously folded, with small remnants of a wax seal.

record.title: Seed lien record : manuscript.
record.note: Title taken from spine.

record.title: Letter from Jno. H. Teitlebaum, East Las Vegas, New Mexico, to Messrs J. W. Rulifson Bro., Lincoln, Nebraska, March 20, 1889 : autograph manuscript, signed.
record.note: Letter written on stationery with lithographed letterhead "Established in 1880. Office of Jno. H Teitlebaum, mortgage, loan and real estate broker ... East Las Vegas, N.M." offering for sale confirmed and patented land at government price in Las Vegas, New Mexico.
Two punch holes through each sheet with slight damage to letterhead.

record.title: Thomas Edwards letter to Sir Dudley North, Clifford's Inn, London, 1683 November 15 : manuscript.
record.note: Docket, probably in the hand of Sir Dudley North: "15 Nov. 1683. Mr. Edwards."

Integral address panel. Cover side contains an example of the first English Penny Post stamp: a triangle bearing the words "Payd peny post" surrounding a capital "T," adjacent to the time stamp "p/af/5" (St. Paul's).

record.title: Assignment of household goods from Bedingfeild Heigham to Thomas White, 1708 May 11 : manuscript.
record.note: Docket: "Assignment of Household goods &c. from B. Heigham to Thomas White."
Document signed: "B. Heigham." Signature followed by red wax seal.
Document signed by two witnesses: "Owen Lloyd" and "Joshua Miles."

record.title: Conveyance between Roger Sadler and William Cecil, Lord Burghley, 1586/1587 January 27 : manuscript.
record.note: Dated at the end of the main text: "vicesimo septimo die Januarii Anno regni d[omi]na n[ost]r[a] Elizabeth...vicesimo nono."
Docketed on verso in two later hands, partially effaced.
Signatures and/or marks of eight witnesses on verso, including the signature of Barnard Dewhurst.

record.title: Worke done for the Kings most excellent maiestie : manuscript.
record.note: Docketed in a contemporary hand: "Ralph Roades rainmaker his Bill. 18 Apr 1662."

record.title: The doctrine of the series, or, Musical rhythm based on common arithmetic : with tables / by Joseph Gersbach ; prepared & published from a fragment left by the author by Anton Gersbach.
record.note: Manuscript.

record.title: [Collection of newspaper clippings of advertisements for theater, performances, and recently published books].
record.note: Collection title devised by cataloger.

record.title: Muster-in roll of Frank North's company, of Pawnee Scouts, called into the service of the United States : manuscript.
record.note: Title taken from first page.
